description: From Middle English impressen, from Latin impressus, perfect passive participle of imprimere (“to press into or upon, stick, stamp, or dig into”), from in (“in, upon”) + premere (“to press”).

entries.meaning: An impression; an impressed image or copy of something.
examples: We know that you were pressed for money, that you took an impress of the keys which your brother held  […]

entries.meaning: A stamp or seal used to make an impression.
An impression on the mind, imagination etc.
examples: Such admonitions, in the English of the Authorized Version, left an indelible impress on imaginations nurtured on the Bible  […]
It commonly occurred that Knights who , on entering the Lists , wished to conceal their identity , would assume a Device with an allusive Motto , which was designated an IMPRESS

entries.meaning: The act of impressing, or taking by force for the public service; compulsion to serve; also, that which is impressed.

verbs.description: impress (third-person singular simple present impresses, present participle impressing, simple past and past participle impressed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To affect (someone) strongly and often favourably.
examples: You impressed me with your command of Urdu.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To make an impression, to be impressive.
examples: Henderson impressed in his first game as captain.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To produce a vivid impression of (something).
examples: That first view of the Eiger impressed itself on my mind.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To mark or stamp (something) using pressure.
examples: We impressed our footprints in the wet cement.

entries.meaning: To produce (a mark, stamp, image, etc.); to imprint (a mark or figure upon something).
(figurative) To fix deeply in the mind; to present forcibly to the attention, etc.; to imprint; to inculcate.
examples: impress the motives and methods of persuasion upon our own hearts, till we feel the force and power of them.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To compel (someone) to serve in a military force.
examples: The press gang used to impress people into the Navy.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To seize or confiscate (property) by force.
examples: The liner was impressed as a troop carrier.
